metadata.title: Nanotoxicity of engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) to environmentally relevant beneficial soil bacteria – a critical review

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 24 April 2018 Revised 1 September 2018 Accepted 4 September 2018
KEYWORDS Environmental nanotoxicology; plant growthpromoting rhizobacteria (PGPR); nanoparticle toxicity; engineered nanomaterials (ENMs); metal toxicity

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Engineered nanomaterials (ENMs), anthropogenically produced materials with at least one dimension between 1 and 100 nm (Pan and Xing 2012), possess unique physicochemical and electrical properties that only manifest at the nanoscale (Verma and Stellacci 2010), and these properties may be exploited to create new materials or to enhance a seemingly endless number of extant materials. The rapid increase in ENM-containing products entering the market is coupled with an inevitable increase of intentional and unintentional releases to the environment (Nowack and Bucheli 2007). Understanding the potential impact of ENMs to the ecosystem and
human health is critical (Oberd€orster et al. 2005; Unrine et al. 2008; Klaine et al. 2012; Gonzalez and Kirsch-Volders 2016; Mitrano and Nowack 2017; Lead et al. 2018).
Much of the research on the environmental toxicology of ENMs has focused on aquatic organisms (Klaine et al. 2008; Maurer-Jones et al. 2013); however, material flow analysis and risk evaluation suggests a majority of ENMs will ultimately be deposited in soils via the wastewater treatment-biosolid-land application pathway (Gottschalk et al. 2009; Judy and Bertsch 2014). There is growing interest in the study of ENM behavior in terrestrial systems, but the complexities of working with

nanoscale materials (i.e. system-induced particle transformation) in complex media, such as soil, have posed significant challenges (Dinesh et al. 2012; Pan and Xing 2012; Judy and Bertsch 2014; Djuri si c et al. 2015). Soil micro-organisms are the primary drivers for delivering ecosystem services in soil, including nutrient and carbon cycling as well as immobilization, degradation, and detoxification of contaminants, leading to overall maintenance of soil health (Torsvik and Øvreås 2002; Nannipieri et al. 2003; Sacc a et al. 2017). An important subset of bacteria found to directly and indirectly promote plant growth is known as plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria (PGPR). PGPR play key roles related to plant health, including plant protective responses to pathogens, drought tolerance, and nutrient acquisition (Dardanelli et al. 2010; Vejan et al. 2016; Etesami and Maheshwari 2018; Shameer and Prasad 2018).
Given the importance of PGPR to plant health, terrestrial ecosystem function, and agroecosystem function and crop yields, understanding potential
impacts of ENMs on PGPR is crucial. Despite the importance of PGPR, there is little research examining their responses to ENMs, particularly regarding plant growth promotion activity. Additionally, as is the case with numerous nanotoxicological studies, the complex behavior of ENMs has posed challenges to understanding PGPR–ENM interactions. This is of particular concern when bacterial responses to ENMs are examined in rhizosphere and bulk soils, soil slurries, wetland microcosms, and in biosolids, where the heterogeneous environment and biological activity may lead to various ENM transformations (Mudunkotuwa and Grassian 2015). As such, a mechanistic understanding of ENM-bacteria interactions has primarily been pursued using pure-culture methods (where solution chemistry can be easily controlled) and ‘pristine’ ENMs (which have not undergone environmental transformations).
However, pristine ENMs are still subject to media/matrix-induced transformations in pure-culture systems (Figure 1; Tejamaya et al. 2012; Moore et al. 2015; Merrifield et al. 2017), so it is necessary
to thoroughly characterize ENMs even in relatively simple minimal exposure media. Along with primary particle size and concentration/particle number, important particle characteristics to consider are dissolution, surface area, aggregation status, morphology, size distribution, zeta-potential/electrophoretic mobility, nature and integrity of capping agents, and particle transformations, which should all ideally be characterized/measured in the exposure medium (Figures 1–3; El Badawy et al. 2011; Raghupathi et al. 2011; Albanese et al. 2012; Georgantzopoulou et al. 2012; Reidy et al. 2013; Ivask, Kurvet, et al. 2014; Djuri si c et al. 2015; Sirelkhatim et al. 2015; Ge et al. 2016; Schmid and Stoeger 2016; Lewis et al. 2017; Mitrano and Nowack 2017; Graf et al. 2018; Ha et al. 2018). After thorough particle characterization in the exposure media, experimental design needs to include the necessary positive and negative controls. In studies where nanomaterials remain uncharacterized or particle transformations are not controlled for, it is not
possible to attribute unique toxicological responses to nanoscale properties of the materials.
A growing body of literature has/is examined(ing) the toxicity of several environmentally relevant nanomaterials to PGPR and related species, often not meeting the requirements of characterization and appropriate controls outlined above. This review presents an expansive and critical evaluation of the literature on PGPR-ENM interactions and suggests a strategy for better clarifying and identifying toxicity mechanisms and relevant risks of ENM to PGPR. Some key findings involving non-PGPR bacteria are also included in the discussion to help inform areas where there are specific knowledge gaps for PGPR, along with findings involving Pseudomonas (P.) aeruginosa, some strains of which might promote plant growth (Radhapriya et al. 2015). There is an intentional focus on metal-containing ENMs because they are known to be toxic to bacteria and are increasing exponentially in key environmental compartments as a result of the volume/mass used in consumer
products and their release/disposal pathways (Gottschalk et al. 2009; Keller et al. 2013; Sun et al. 2014; Mitrano and Nowack 2017). For those interested specifically in PGPR-ENM interactions, this review provides a complete resource with extensive summary tables and figures provided alongside insights into how to properly perform
nanotoxicological studies to minimize experimental artifacts, with a specific focus on metal-based ENMs. Those interested in carbon-based nanomaterials are directed to other work (Gottschalk et al. 2015; Riding et al. 2015; Lehndorff et al. 2016; Chen, Qin, et al. 2017; Lian and Xing 2017; Lin e et al. 2017; Rong et al. 2017; Vithanage et al. 2017; Chen, Zhou,

sections.heading: Ag ENMs and PGPR in perspective
sections.text: Silver-containing ENMs (Ag ENMs) are among the most abundant commercially produced nanomaterials, and environmental concentrations are expected to rise significantly over the next several decades (Gottschalk et al. 2009; Keller et al. 2013; Sun et al. 2014; Mitrano and Nowack 2017). While the effects of silver release to the environment from its use as an antibiotic, an electrical conductor, and in the now largely defunct photographic processing industry have long been recognized, the unique physiochemical properties of nanoscale silver raise many new questions regarding possible environmental fate and effects of the silver released from exponential increases in Ag ENM use. Understanding bacterial responses to Ag ENMs both in pure-culture and in the environment remains difficult for several reasons: (1) Ag ENMs readily undergo dissolution in aerobic environments and the mechanisms of toxicity and resistance/tolerance to silver ions from Ag ENMs are still not fully understood; (2) there is uncertainty regarding the mechanisms of toxicity of environmentally transformed particles, namely, sulfidized Ag ENMs (sAg ENMs) (Reinsch et al. 2012; Chen, Unrine, et al. 2015; Wang et al. 2015; Lewis et al. 2017); (3) Ag ENMs may interact with cells directly; (4) Ag ENMs and Agþ may generate reactive oxygen species (ROS); and (5) the relative importance of particle size, shape, capping agent, surface charge, and surface area on bacterial toxicity remains unresolved (Mitrano and Nowack 2017). Despite the difficulty in examining Ag ENM toxicity mechanisms, the multiple uses and expected environmental release of these materials have resulted in considerable research efforts. However, few studies have focused on the responses of PGPR to Ag ENMs and other ENMs, particularly in the context of plant growth promotion. There is still much to understand regarding the toxicity of nanomaterials to bacteria compared with their bulk or ion equivalents; nevertheless, the following sections provide a review of what is known concerning Ag ENM toxicity to PGPR.

sections.heading: Ag ENM toxicity and the Bacillus genus
sections.text:
The Bacillus genus is utilized to generate the most commercially developed PGPR, primarily because this genus forms endospores resulting in environmentally stable products with long shelf-lives (Kokalis-Burelle et al. 2006). Bacillus (B.) subtilis is a model bacterium (Harwood et al. 1990) of ecological, agricultural, and economic importance that is found in human, plant, and soil microbiomes. Many B. subtilis strains demonstrate plant growthpromoting capabilities that have been attributed to disease suppression and production of antibiotics, as discussed by Kokalis-Burelle et al. (2006). Additionally, B. subtilis and related species may induce systemic resistance in plants yielding enhanced resistance to common pathogens (Kloepper et al. 2004).
Various strains of B. subtilis have been used in nanotoxicological studies (Dinesh et al. 2012; Maurer-Jones et al. 2013; Suresh et al. 2013). Ruparelia et al. (2008) showed that different strains of the same bacterial species may respond differently to silver and copper ENMs. For instance, the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC; the minimum concentration of a substance required to completely inhibit growth) of silver nanoparticles to Escherichia (E.) coli MTCC 443 was 0.37mM, which was the same for B. subtilis MTCC 441, while E. coli MTCC 739 and MTCC 1302 had MIC’s of 1.67mM and 1.11mM, respectively. The toxicity of Ag ENMs to the different strains of Staphylococcus (S.) aureus (NCIM 2079, 5021, and 5022) resulted in the same MIC value (1.1mM). Feng et al. (2000) found the Gram-positive bacteria, S. aureus, was more resistant to morphological changes induced by Agþ compared with E. coli, while Yoon et al. (2007) found B. subtilis was more sensitive to both silver and copper nanoparticles than E. coli. For instance, the C90 (the concentration where survival¼ 10%) was 297 mM and 541.2mM for B. subtilis and E. coli, respectively. Jin et al. (2010) found P. putida to be generally more tolerant to Ag ENM exposure compared with B. subtilis and, not surprisingly, due to the influence of particle behavior and chemical speciation of dissolved silver, that mortality responses are greatly influenced by the presence of ions (i.e. Ca2þ, Mg2þ, Naþ, Kþ, SOSO2 4 , HCO 3 ) in solution. For instance, in the presence of Ca and Mg, the IC50 for Ag ENMs
was roughly five times greater for P. putida depending on the other salts present. The responses are likely due to changes in metal speciation and availability resulting from differences in solution chemistry with each ionic treatment (especially because pH ranged from 5.4 to 8.9). Furthermore, as the authors suggested, solution chemistry-induced changes in bacterial physiology and Ag ENM aggregation status/dissolution could influence metal toxicity. Mosselhy et al. (2015) observed that P. putida KT2442 was more sensitive to Agþ compared with B. subtilis Ehrenberg with 9.3 and 93 mM Agþ required for complete mortality of the strains, respectively. Neither strain was affected by up to 93 mM of 8 and 29 nm polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP)capped Ag ENMs (PVP-Ag ENMs) in liquid culture. In another study, the toxicity of nano-colloidal silver (1-100 nm primary particle size, no reported capping agent) to several Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria (including B. cereus) was independent of Gram stain status (Petrus et al. 2011). One study which examined the toxicity of particle–microbe interactions in de-ionized water in the absence of potentially confounding medium constituents, found either Gram-positive or Gram-negative was more susceptible to Ag ENM toxicity depending on the endpoint measured (Kim et al. 2011). Patil et al. (2018) observed exposure of B. cereus ATCC 13061 and P. putida ATCC 49128 to 10–20 nm Ag ENMs (AgCl-coated) resulted in a MIC¼ 556 mM for both organisms; however, the MBC (minimum bactericidal concentration) was 649 and 834 mM for B. cereus and P. putida, respectively. Others observed similar responses when B. subtilis AST5-2 and P. aeruginosa AL2-14B were exposed to 40–60 nm spherical citrate-coated Ag ENMs (citrate-Ag ENMs) (MIC¼ 1.8 and 1.7mM, respectively) or 20 nm nanorod Ag ENMs, MIC¼ 3.2mM for both species (Acharya et al. 2018). These results demonstrate the complexity of extracting generalized conclusions from the literature regarding the responses of Gram-positive versus Gram-negative bacteria in pure-culture as they are likely conflated by being influenced by the test organisms, exposure media, and characteristics of ENMs which are generally not fully explored.
The use of various bacterial strains and experimental protocols in Ag ENM toxicity studies (Figure 4(A,B)) has yielded a wide range in reported toxicity
responses as measured by end-points like MICs and the zone of inhibition (ZOI) (Figure 4(C,D) and Table S1). Zone of inhibition, or Kirby–Bauer, tests are often used in bacteriological studies to test for the toxicity of an agent to bacteria. These studies can be performed in several ways, but most commonly the toxicant being tested is placed in the center of an agar plate (dropwise or on a filter disk) on which a bacterial suspension had previously been spread, and the plate is incubated and the area of growth inhibition around the toxicant is measured afterwards. Using this method to test the toxicity of nanoparticles has resulted in a broad range of responses. For instance, Bhakya et al. (2016) reported a 5mm ZOI in B. subtilis ATCC 25923 exposed to 930 mM Helicteres isora-derived Ag ENMs (16–95 nm, 19mV zeta-potential), while Caki c et al. (2016) reported a ZOI of 19mm in B. subtilis ATCC 6633 and B. cereus ATCC 11778 exposed to 9. 3mM dextran-sulfate-coated Ag ENMs (10–60 nm). This is a much larger than the ZOI of 11mm reported by Ruparelia et al. (2008) in B. subtilis ATCC 6633 in response to 2 nm uncoated Ag ENMs, and is likely due primarily to differences in particle surface chemistry. Fatima et al. (2016) reported a ZOI of 1.4 and 1.8mm in B. cereus and B. subtilis, respectively, exposed to 150 mM biogenic Ag ENMs (25–50 nm, Aspergillus flavus-derived). In another study, B. subtilis NCIB 3610 exposed to 5mg total Ag ENMs (13.5 nm suspended particle size, Thermotoga maritima-derived) exhibited a ZOI of 13mm (Giessen and Silver 2016), which is similar to the 14mm ZOI observed in B. cereus NCIM 2106 exposed to 232 mM Ag ENMs (25 nm, Prunus japonica-derived) (Saravanakumar et al. 2017). Shivananda et al. (2016) reported a zone of inhibition of 11–16mm in B. subtilis MTCC 121 exposed to varying concentrations (3.6–116 mM) and sizes of Ag ENMs (13.4–40.6 nm, Bombyx mori silk-derived); this same bacterial strain exhibited a ZOI of 7.3 and 12.3mm when exposed to chemically synthesized (uncharacterized) versus biologically synthesized (5–50 nm, P. fluorescens-derived) Ag ENMs (Syed et al. 2016). Interestingly, another B. subtilis strain exhibited a ZOI of 12.7mm to another biogenic Ag ENM (Cordyseps militaris-derived) (Shivananda et al. 2016). Notably, all of these studies resulted in responses indicating ENM toxicity, but the magnitude of those responses was different. These results
emphasize again the importance of closely considering the experimental protocol used when interpreting the observed response from ENM exposure.
Like the ZOI test, reported Ag ENM toxicity responses as measured by MICs in soil bacteria also exhibit a broad range (Figure 4(A) and Table S1). For example, Suresh et al. (2010) examined the toxicity of AgNO3, biogenic Ag ENMs (4 nm, zetapotential¼ 12mV, Shewanella (Sh.) oneidensis MR-1derived), pyridine-Ag ENMs (4 nm, zetapotential¼ 45.8mV), and oleate-Ag ENMs (9 nm, zeta-potential¼ 42.5mV) to B. subtilis ATCC 9372,
Sh. oneidensis MR-1, and E. coli ATCC 25922. AgNO3 was the most toxic, but biogenic particles were the most toxic of the ENMs or colloids, which is likely because they had the greatest amount of dissolution, even if (as suggested by the authors) the dissolved fraction did not fully explain toxicity (Table S1). Notably, MICs were 5 and 19 mM for biogenic Ag ENMs versus pyridine-coated silver colloids, which is much lower than that reported by Ruparelia et al. (2008) in B. subtilis ATCC 6633 (370 mM, Figure 4 and Table S1). B. subtilis MTCC 121 exhibited a broad range of MICs in response to

Bombyx mori silk-derived ENMs, with increasing AgNO3 concentrations used in synthesis resulting in larger ENMs but lower MICs, which suggests greater free ion availability in solutions with larger ENMs (Shivananda et al. 2016). Doody et al. (2016) observed reductions in growth (as determined via growth curve) of B. subtilis UD1022 in response to 46 mM citrate-coated Ag ENMs (44.9 nm, zetapotential¼ 13mV), while Kwak et al. (2016) reported a 12-h EC50 of 1.1mM PVP-Ag ENM (23–76 nm, zeta-potential¼ 1.2mV) for B. subtilis KACC 10111. The array of bacterial strains and ENMs used in these studies make it difficult to make direct comparisons. Greater ENM characterization (especially dissolution measurements) would likely help clarify at least some of the variance in reported toxicity responses, which is supported by the ENMs with the greatest toxicity having the greatest dissolution in the work of
Suresh et al. (2010), and the minimal toxicity observed by Doody et al. (2016) when dissolution was low.
While abiotic ENM dissolution in media is an important indicator of toxicity in many experimental systems, particle–cell interactions are known to enhance toxicity of Ag ENMs and studies using silver biosensors and dissolution measurements suggest biotic dissolution of Ag ENMs and intracellular silver concentrations also explain much of the toxicity (Bondarenko et al. 2013; Ivask, Elbadawy, et al. 2014). A major finding of Sondi and Salopek-Sondi (2004) is that silver nanoparticles may attach to and cause ‘pitting’ of the bacterial surface (Figure 5(A,B)). This phenomenon has been confirmed by some studies (Morones et al. 2005; Li et al. 2010) (Figure 5(C,D)), but not all (Gambino et al. 2015; Figure 5(E,F)).
