pitting, it has been proposed that ENM dissolution at the particle–cell interface drives fragmentation of peptidoglycan strands, leading to compromised cell walls and/or that ENM-generated ROS assists in membrane disruption (Priester et al. 2009; Mirzajani et al. 2011). There is also evidence that many bacterial species may form nanoparticles both extracellularly or intracellularly (Singh et al. 2015), and that nanoparticles may be formed from commonly used staining agents used in transmission electron microscopy (Djuri si c et al. 2015). Suresh et al. (2010), using atomic force microscopy (AFM), showed the biogenic particles induced significant membrane damage to 10% of B. subtilis cells, but not E. coli. The silver colloids were associated with E. coli, but less so with B. subtilis. Near complete mortality was observed in B. subtilis at 23 and 32 mM of biogenic and colloidal ENMs, respectively, while oleate-capped Ag ENMs were not toxic up to 70 mM. The authors measured dissolution of the particles in Luria–Bertani (LB) medium and found that the Agþ from dissolution did not fully explain the increased toxicity of the biogenic ENMs, suggesting biotically driven increases in dissolution or ENMspecific toxicity. Others have observed that abiotically dissolved Agþ likely explained the toxicity of PVP-Ag ENMs in B. amyloliquefaciens GB03, P. putida UW4, and Sinorhizobium (Si.) meliloti 2011 in 50mM 2-morpholin-4-ylethanesulfonic acid (MES) at pH 6 supplemented with 1.25% glucose (Table S1; Lewis et al. 2017). These authors also showed species specific responses to PVP-Ag ENMs in terms of O2 consumption and viability, with moderate and highly elevated O2 consumption observed in B. amyloliquefaciens and P. putida, respectively, while Si. meliloti exhibited elevated or reduced O2 consumption depending on the concentration of the Ag ENMs (Table S1). Xiu et al. (2012) utilized the fact that Agþ solubility was very low in anaerobic conditions (Ag ENM dissolution was measured) and showed Ag ENMs were toxic to E. coli ATCC 25404 in aerobic conditions but not anaerobic conditions, while Agþ demonstrated similar toxicity under both states. While these results suggest the mechanism of toxicity in E. coli is driven primarily by dissolution of Agþ, it is not clear how other alterations in microbial physiology and/or ENM transformations may have affected the response to Ag ENMs in aerobic versus anaerobic conditions. While the dissolved
silver fraction often explains the toxicity of Ag ENMs, it is clear from transcriptomic studies that the pattern of gene expression in E. coli was different for AgNO3 compared with Ag ENMs (Ivask, Elbadawy, et al. 2014; McQuillan and Shaw 2014); a pattern that was also influenced by particle coatings and size (Ivask, Elbadawy, et al. 2014). These studies show that, while intracellular silver concentrations and dissolved silver may be good predictors of toxicity, there are certainly other important aspects of particle–cell interactions influencing toxicity.
Perhaps the most extensive study of PGPR–Ag ENM interactions to date is the work of Gambino et al. (2015). The authors examined growth responses of planktonic cells of B. subtilis Cu1065 and Azotobacter (A.) vinelandii UW136 to commercially purchased Ag ENMs (8.3 nm, zetapotential¼ 19mV) and found 930 mM Ag ENM in Tryptic Soy Broth (TSB) was required to induce reduction in B. subtilis growth, while as little as 0.93mM Ag ENM significantly reduced generation times of A. vinelandii. Imaging via transmission electron microscopy (TEM) showed non-homogenous distribution of the particles on the surface and within planktonic B. subtilis cells, while no membrane damage was observed. This finding suggests particle dissolution followed by uptake of Agþ and intracellular formation of nanoparticles, or transmembrane transport of Ag ENMs. The authors also utilized several assays to examine metabolic and functional responses of B. subtilis planktonic cells to Ag ENMs and found no effect on swarming or swimming motility, production of indole-3 acetic acid (IAA), or siderophores, but increased solubilization of inorganic phosphate by 100%. Intracellular ROS levels were reduced by 80% in response to 9.3mM Ag ENM compared with no Ag ENMs, but increased by 300% in response to 93 mM in planktonic cultures, while intra/extracellular ROS levels were either unaltered or reduced by Ag ENMs in B. subtilis biofilms. Total protein levels were found to be reduced by 43% at 2–3 d of growth in biofilms by 93 mM Ag ENM, while 9.3 mM increased total protein by 41% at 4 d; however, no influence on total protein was observed after 8 d of growth by either treatment.
Importantly, both 9.3 and 93 mM Ag ENM were found to markedly increase production of
extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) by 300% in 5-d old B. subtilis biofilms, while no significant effects were observed on concentrations of environmental DNA (eDNA – DNA released from the cells) or total protein (Gambino et al. 2015). Increased extra polymeric substances (EPS) production in response to Ag ENM exposure is particularly relevant given that addition of EPS to E. coli cultures exposed to Agþ led to reduction of ions to nanoparticles, which mitigated toxicity (Kang et al. 2014) and various others have found EPS plays a role in Ag ENM toxicity (Table S1). Gene ontology (GO) analyses showed upregulation of proteins from several annotated GO term groups in B. subtilis biofilms exposed to 9.3 and 93 mM Ag ENMs. Stress–response proteins were related to oxidative stress and redox status of the cell along with other stress responses. Proteins involved in primary metabolism, transcription, translation, and quorum sensing were also upregulated. While the work of Gambino et al. (2015) is expansive and informative, there is a need to clarify the mechanisms underlying the observed responses by including silver ion controls, and characterization of Ag ENMs in the exposure medium in future studies.
Studies examining the response of the Bacillus genus to Ag ENMs have resulted in a wide range of toxicity in terms of MIC, ZOI, membrane integrity, and other end-points, which can be driven by either bacterial strain, ENM characteristics, or other experimental parameters (medium chemistry). Clearly, both abiotically and biotically dissolved Agþ play a key role in toxicity of Ag ENMs in bacilli, which, again, is likely attenuated by experimental parameters (i.e. medium). While some work has been done examining the effect of Ag ENMs on biofilm formation in B. subtilis, future work should aim to explore the phenomenon in greater depth and in other bacilli, other genera, and multi-species biofilms. Furthermore, little remains known regarding the transcriptomic, proteomic, and metabolomic response of bacilli to Ag ENMs, which presents a vast field of exploration capable of revealing fundamental biological mechanisms driving ENM toxicity.

sections.heading: Ag ENM toxicity and the Pseudomonas genus
sections.text:
Fluorescent pseudomonads may provide plant growth promotion via biocontrol of soil borne
fungal pathogens (Haas and Keel 2003). These microbes suppress the growth of fungal pathogens in the rhizosphere by producing antifungal metabolites, which act upon the fungi, and iron chelators, which reduce the availability of iron to other competing microbes, as discussed by Haas and Keel (2003). At least one strain of P. fluorescens, CHA0, is capable of producing 2,4-diacetylphoroglucinol, a molecule exhibiting antifungal activity as well as bactericidal and phytotoxic activity (Keel et al. 1992).
In the Pseudomonas genus, much research has been directed at understanding the effects of Ag ENMs on biofilm formation, which is crucial to root colonization (Rudrappa et al. 2008). Hartmann et al. (2013) developed a modified chip calorimetric method to examine the effects of nanoparticles on growth inhibition and inactivation of P. putida mt-2 KT2440 and PaW340 grown on agarose beads. As little as 0.09mM Ag ENM (38.8 nm, no reported coating) inhibited biofilm formation in P. putida mt-2, while 4.6mM Ag ENM completely inhibited biofilm formation. Both 0.74 and 4.6mM Ag ENM significantly inactivated cells of established biofilms. Roughly 9.3mM Ag ENMs were sufficient to damage biofilms of P. putida PaW340. Ag ENMs were found to heavily aggregate in the minimal exposure medium (Table S1), demonstrating a mean diameter of 42 nm in stock solutions and 675 nm in diluted solutions. Moreover, the exposure medium likely influenced the response because it contained Cl , which may enhance the availability of sulfidized Ag ENMs (sAg ENMs) (Wang, Menzies, Dennis, et al. 2016), and SOSO2 4 , which can result in low solubility Ag2SO4 precipitates. Still, this work presents a unique method which could be useful in future endeavors examining ENM toxicity to biofilms.
Fabrega, Fawcett, et al. (2009) examined the influence of organic matter and pH (6, 7.5, and 9) on the toxicity of citrate–Ag ENMs (65–100 nm, electrophoretic mobility¼ 2 to 4 cm2 V 1s 1) to P. fluorescens in Minimal Davidson Medium (MDM). An elevated pH of 9 increased the toxicity of citrate–Ag ENMs at 18.5mM by 50%. Suwannee River humic acids (SRHA) at 10mg L 1 completely mitigated the toxic responses after 24 h of exposure and even induced growth after 3 h of exposure relative to SRHA minus controls. The authors reported disaggregation of the Ag ENMs induced by SRHA and
observed no effect of SRHA on Agþ toxicity. This suggests, as the authors stated, that under the conditions of this experiment, humic substances either form poor complexes with silver, or silver–humic substance complexes are bioavailable. They further speculated that the SRHA-induced reduction of Ag ENM toxicity could be due to an antioxidant effect which mitigates oxidative damage from Ag ENM; however, humic acid has been shown to increase the toxicity of 15–25 nm citrate-Ag ENMs to natural bacterial assemblages in dark and sunlight conditions (Dasari and Hwang 2010). For instance, 40mg L 1 SRHA along with 2.5 mM Ag ENMs resulted in a 95% reduction in CFU mL 1 compared with the Ag ENMs alone. Sunlight increased ROS production, with essentially no ROS formed in dark conditions and up to a 400% increase in fluorescence measurements of ROS production in light conditions (Dasari and Hwang 2010). Dasari and Hwang (2010) also generally observed greater Ag ENM toxicity in the presence of river humic acid compared with terrestrial humic acid, suggesting the importance of humic substance composition in nanotoxicity studies.
Fabrega, Renshaw, et al. (2009) also examined the effect of pH and organic matter on the toxicity of the same citrate-Ag ENMs to P. putida OUS82 biofilms, also in MDM. Here the authors reported 5% reductions in biovolume per surface area (BVSA) of the biofilms exposed to 0.185, 1.85, and 18.5 mM Ag ENMs at pH 6, and found similar reductions with 1.85 and 18.5 mM Ag ENMs at pH 7.5. Under both pH conditions, 10mg L 1 Suwannee River fulvic acid (SRFA) mitigated the effect on BVSA even as SRFA increased silver uptake by 100% in biofilms at 18.5mM silver. Given that 18.5 mM Ag ENM was not previously found to reduce viability at pH 6 (Fabrega, Fawcett, et al. 2009), these results indicate that biofilm BVSA may be a sensitive end-point for examining Ag ENM toxicity.
PVP-Ag ENMs with either ‘low stability’ (LS) or ‘high stability’ (HS) (determined via direct-light scattering) effectively reduced biofilm biomass of established P. fluorescens biofilms in MDM, with 800 mM LS PVP-Ag ENMs reducing biomass by 30%, and 89 and 890 mM HS PVP-Ag ENMs reducing biomass by >50% and 70%, respectively (Wirth et al. 2012). Natural organic matter (humic acid) was
found to mitigate the toxicity of both particle types and their particle-free supernatants. HS PVP-Ag ENMs (89 mM) reduced biofilm biomass by 100% more than the associated particle-free supernatants, indicating particle-specific toxic effects at this concentration. Together, these studies examining the effect of humic substances on silver–biofilm interactions show the importance of experimental design in nanotoxicity studies, particularly the pH of the exposure medium and the form of organic matter used.
The influence of ENMs on signaling in biofilms has also been investigated in pseudomonads. In a study by Radzig et al. (2013), biofilm formation of P. aeruginosa PAO1 was almost completely inhibited by 83 mM hydrolyzed casein-stabilized Ag ENM (8.3 nm) in Nutrient Broth medium. Also, the Luxl/ LuxR quorum-sensing systems were not found to be involved in the response. However, Yang and Alverez (2015) found that 0.2 or 1.0mM PVP-coated Ag ENMs (PVP-Ag ENMs) significantly induced (>1- fold) the quorum-sensing genes, LasR and Lasl, respectively, in P. aeruginosa PAO1 in Davies minimal nutrient broth. LPS (lipopolysaccharide) biosynthesis genes were also upregulated (>1-fold) in response to 0.2 or 1 mM PVP-Ag ENMs, sagS and pslA, respectively, and 0.2 mM PVP-Ag ENMs was found to increase carbohydrate (35%) and protein concentrations (100%) in the biofilm matrix. Antibiotic resistance genes were induced by 0.2 mM PVP-Ag ENMs. Exposure of P. aeruginosa to equimolar concentrations of PVP-Ag ENMs and Agþ revealed greater toxicity of PVP-Ag ENMs for a number of endpoints (quorum sensing, LPS biosynthesis, and antibiotic resistance). Radzig et al. (2013) also suggested DNA damage in E. coli in response to Ag ENMs and found a 4–8 fold increase in resistance to Ag ENMs in mutant strains deficient in either OmpF or OmpC, both are outer membrane proteins. Why some studies reveal signaling responses and others do not is unclear. Future studies might investigate the phenomenon using signaling knock-out mutants and a variety of ENM–medium combinations.
Some important considerations when assessing ENM toxicity to biofilms are the growth stage of the organism along with the conditions of the exposure. For instance, the growth stage of P. putida KT2440 biofilms was found to influence
responses to polyvinyl alcohol-stabilized Ag ENMs in LB medium, with stage 3 (48 h) biofilms showing a greater tolerance to the particles than stage 1 (12 h) or 2 (30 h) biofilms (Thuptimdang et al. 2015). Citric acid-stabilized Ag ENM or Agþ had equal inhibitory effects on P. aeruginosa PAO1 biofilms at 93 mM when the exposure solution (PBS buffer) was stirred, with no observed effect of the Ag ENMs in static conditions (Park et al. 2013). Additionally, compared with anaerobic conditions, aerobic conditions enhanced the toxicity of 23.2 and 46.3mM Ag ENMs (coating not reported, 40 nm determined via DLS) to P. aeruginosa DSM No: 22644 by 6% and 1%, respectively (Chen, Yang, et al. 2017). Given that aeration has a large impact on ENM toxicity, future work might employ such a method when it is relevant (i.e. in cases where microbes are likely to be exposed to ENMs in flowing solutions).
ENM toxicity to pseudomonads has also been examined in planktonic bacterial cultures. Lewis et al. (2017) reported an LC50 of 86.4mM for P. putida UW4 exposed to 60 nm PVP-Ag ENMs, with B. amyloliquefaciens GB03 exhibiting a similar response (LC50¼ 89.7mM). Radzig et al. (2013) found an MIC of 53 mM Ag ENMs in planktonic cultures of P. aeruginosa and P. chlororaphis. Another study examined the toxicity of de novo synthesized nitroxide-capped Ag ENMs to P. aeruginosa ATCC 10145, E. coli AGCC 23546, S. aureus ATCC 29213, S. epidermidis ATCC 12228, or Klebsiella pneumoniae ATCC 13886 (Gozdziewska et al. 2015). The Ag ENMs were well characterized after synthesis and the most toxic particles synthesized yielded MICs in the micromolar range in Mueller–Hinton Broth (37 mM for P. aeruginosa). Similarly, sodium dodecyl sulfatestabilized Ag ENMs (SDS-Ag ENMs), generated through hydrazine hydrate reduction, were found to have an MIC of 63mM to P. aeruginosa CCM 3955 in Mueller–Hinton Broth. Particles generated through citrate/hydrate reduction with or without SDS had higher MICs (2mM and 133–267mM, respectively) (Guzman et al. 2012). These hydrazine hydrate-generated SDS-Ag ENMs were found to be the least toxic to E. coli and two different strains of S. aureus; however, the hydrazine hydrate-generated SDS-Ag ENMs induced the largest zone of inhibition in all tested bacteria. Here, it is worth mentioning that some researchers report similar findings in liquid vs. agar media (Pal et al. 2007), while others
find assay-dependent responses (Sondi and Salopek-Sondi 2004; Kim et al. 2011).
Many relevant pseudomonads produce bluegreen or fluorescent pigments while others have been genetically modified to include the luxCDABE operon as a transcriptional reporter; both have been used to examine ENM toxicity in microbes. For example, Gajjar et al. (2009) examined the toxicity of commercially available Ag, ZnO, and CuO ENMs to P. putida KT2440 (which emits light as a measure of energy production) exposed in sterilized water. The authors found a good correlation between the loss of lux and colony forming unit (CFU) counts of exposed bacteria; however, Ag ENMs were uncharacterized and field flow fractionation revealed CuO and ZnO ENMs had a broad size range of poly-dispersed nanoparticles, with some aggregates being greater than 300 nm. Similarly, Dams et al. (2011) examined the toxicity of commercially available silver micro/nanoparticles to P. putida and showed citric acid-stabilized Ag ENMs (35 nm) induced greater toxicity than microscale particles, but that silver ions induced the greatest toxicity. Additionally, they demonstrated the utility of a bioluminescent strain, P. putida BS566:: luxCDABE, in nanotoxicological studies; however, the particles used in this study also remained uncharacterized, so future work should apply this method to examine differences in responses to Ag ENMs and Agþ while measuring dissolution to place the findings in context.
The effects of surface charge and the presence of EPS on Ag ENM toxicity have also been investigated in pseudomonads. For instance, Dimkpa, Calder, Gajjar, et al. (2011) showed that Ag ENMs (10 nm, zeta-potential¼ 33 to 35mV) had little influence on cell surface charge of P. chlororaphis O6 (PcO6) cells suspended in distilled deionized water, whereas, Agþ ions neutralized surface charge. Likewise, the Agþ ions, but not Ag ENMs, neutralized the negative charge of PcO6 derived EPS. Addition of EPS to EPS-deficient and EPS-containing cells mitigated the toxicity of 14 mM Ag ENM and 14 mM Agþ ion, but not 93 mM Ag ENM. Badireddy et al. (2014) showed that P. aeruginosa is capable of producing Ag ENMs from AgNO3 and that particle formation and stability was enhanced by the presence of EPS and NaCl, compared with natural organic matter (NOM). Also, stripping EPS from
biofilms led to rapid, nearly complete mortality after 30min of exposure in biofilms at multiple developmental stages, while biofilms with intact EPS maintained viability over a 2 h period (Thuptimdang et al. 2015). It is apparent from these findings that EPS plays an important role in Ag ENM toxicity and that the interaction of EPS with silver ions should also be considered.
Research into the influence of Ag ENMs on membrane integrity has yielded a variety of findings. Using atomic force microscopy and periplasmic and cytoplasmic enzyme leakage assays (alkaline phosphatase and cytoplasmically localized GFP, respectively), Dimkpa, Calder, Gajjar, et al. (2011) reported no significant damage to inner or outer membranes induced by Ag ENMs. AFM micrographs of P. aeruginosa ATCC 27317 exposed to 17.5 nm citrate-Ag ENM or 38.8 nm 11-mercaptoundecanoic acidcapped Ag ENMs or AgNO3 showed no signs of membrane disruption in response to any of the metals (Dorobantu et al. 2015). These authors showed that citrate-capped Ag ENMs were much less toxic than 11-mercaptoundecanoic acid-capped particles and that the latter were observed in higher numbers in association with the cell surface. Furthermore, Ag ENMs or AgNO3 were not found to disrupt the membranes of S. aureus or Saccharomyces cerevisiae, while AgNO3 led to cellular lysing and collapse of algal cells (Euglena gracilis and Chlorella prototheciodes). The authors speculated that citrate-capped Ag ENMs were more stable compared with 11-mercaptoundecanoic acidcapped particles and that the lower stability particles likely more readily released Agþ ions; however, measurements of dissolved Agþ were not reported. Still, it is unlikely that complete dissolution of the particles explains the observed toxicity, as equimolar concentrations of AgNO3 were more toxic. Also, cells were exposed to Ag ENMs or AgNO3 in water suspensions while controls were maintained in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). These findings are similar to those of Gambino et al. (2015), which reported no ENM-induced membrane damage in B. subtilis; however, many studies show cell wall pitting and/or membrane disruption in response to nanomaterial exposure (Sondi and Salopek-Sondi 2004; Pal et al. 2007; Fabrega, Fawcett, et al. 2009; Gajjar et al. 2009).
For instance, Priester et al. (2014) found E. coli was less susceptible to cysteine-capped Ag ENMs compared with P. aeruginosa, as measured by viability and membrane integrity, and membrane damage was induced by Ag ENM exposure. The authors suggested that abiotic dissolution of ENMs in the media (LB, Modified Minimal Davis (MMD)) explained the toxic responses and patterns in specific growth rate reduction induced by AgNO3 or Ag ENMs were found to overlap in terms of dissolved Agþ. Additionally, abiotic ROS and Agþ concentrations were positively correlated with a reduction in membrane integrity, with the effect being more prominent in P. aeruginosa. Others have found that intracellular ROS was not associated with Ag ENM toxicity, but increased ROS was observed in cells exposed to 9.3–14 mM Agþ, which induced a 150 and 300% increase in ROS measurements, respectively (Dimkpa, Calder, Gajjar, et al. 2011). Addition of ROS scavengers during exposure reduced the toxicity of 14 mM Ag ENMs or Agþ (catalase addition completely mitigated Ag ENM toxicity and restored CFU mL 1 to nearly 90% in ion exposures), suggesting a role for extracellular ROS production. This is unlike the result of Gambino et al. (2015), which showed Ag ENMs had no effect, or reduced, measured extracellular ROS. A study by Hachicho et al. (2014) showed citrate-Ag ENM (10 nm) concentrations up to 6mM in supplemented mineral salt medium resulted in a linear increase from 0.1 to 0.8 in trans/cis ratios of unsaturated fatty acids of P. putida mt-2 (DSM 6125) cells, while a ratio of 0.8 was observed in response to 1.9 mM Agþ ions (Table S1), indicating possible decreased membrane fluidity. Total silver in either treatment appeared to partly explain the observed responses; however, the amount of Ag ENMs necessary to completely inhibit growth was higher than AgNO3 (3.2 versus 1.7mM, respectively). Matzke et al. (2014) examined the toxicity of many sized Ag ENMs with either tannic or citric acid or unspecified coatings and found no effect of size or coating on observed growth responses of P. putida DSM 50026 in minimal medium (Table S1). EC50s of all tested materials were in the nanomolar range (1. 5–124 nM); however, particle characterization in the exposure medium (which contained significant amounts of K2HPO4/KH2PO4, MgSO4, NaNO3, and iron citrate) was not possible, so it is difficult to
speculate regarding nano-specific effects. Future studies might clarify these results by characterizing the particles in the exposure medium and by incorporating particle size/coating combinations in a factorial experimental design. It is unclear why some studies reveal ENM-induced changes in membrane integrity and composition while others do not. It could be that, prior to imaging, particles are delivered to the cell surface during sample preparation in some cases and not others, and it is likely that some experimental procedures promote particle–cell interactions while others do not.
The effect of Ag ENMs on gene expression and protein regulation has also been investigated in pseudomonads. For example, proteins and mRNA transcripts of ribosomal proteins S2 and L9, alkyl hydroperoxide reductase/thiol-specific antioxidant (AhpC/TSA) family protein, and keto-hydroxyglutarate aldolase (KHGA) were upregulated (1.09-, 1.56- ,1.52-, and 3.41-fold mRNA expression levels), in a soil isolated Pseudomonas sp. upon exposure to sublethal doses of 20–30 nm Ag ENMs (0.93 mM) in minimal medium (Table S1; Soni et al. 2014). The MIC of Ag ENMs was 1.9 mM, and metabolic activity and absorbance (600 nm) correlated well in a dosedependent manner. However, particles were uncharacterized in the exposure medium and no silver ion controls were used, so further studies are needed to determine the underlying chemical/biological mechanisms eliciting the molecular responses. Yan et al. (2018) observed PVP-Ag ENMs (5 nm) induced stronger changes ROS- and membrane-related protein expression compared with AgNO3 in studies with P. aeruginosa ATC 10145. These results together suggest that Ag ENM exposure induces widespread changes in protein expression related to basic metabolism, membrane functioning, and ROS responses.
Pseudomonads have received a great deal of attention regarding ENM toxicity, and, while the basic physicochemical and biological mechanisms governing ENM–pseudomonad interactions remain to be clearly elucidated. Still, studies examining the toxicity of Ag ENMs to pseudomonads have revealed the importance of EPS in attenuating toxicity in biofilms, as well as the importance of experimental conditions on the phenomenon (e.g. static versus non-static conditions, pH, and organic matter type). The effect of Ag ENMs on signaling in
biofilms requires further work to clarify the results presented in this section and signaling in planktonic cells should also be further investigated. As with the Bacillus genus, little is known regarding the transcriptomic, proteomic, and metabolomic response of plant growth-promoting pseudomonads to Ag ENM exposure, and the various bacterial strains and experimental procedures implemented in exploring nanotoxicity have resulted in a range of reported toxicological responses. The reader is directed to Figure 4 and Table S1 for a complete summary of reviewed Ag ENM toxicity studies with pseudomonads; this figure and table summarize many of the findings of references cited above along with many others (Chowdhury et al. 2016; Mallevre, Alba, et al. 2016, Mallevre, Fernandes, et al. 2016; Netala et al. 2016; Quinteros et al. 2016; Ramalingam et al. 2016; Sahu et al. 2016; Bertuccio and Tilton 2017; Dong et al. 2017; Fennell et al. 2017; Skandalis et al. 2017; Thuptimdang et al. 2017; Yuan et al. 2017; He et al. 2018; Nate et al. 2018). Future researchers should use these studies as a foundation to examine the molecular and behavioral responses of pseudomonads (and other bacteria) in response to ENMs to develop a better understanding of biological mechanisms involved in ENM responses.

sections.heading: Sulfidized Ag ENM toxicity and PGPR
sections.text:
Many engineered nanomaterials enter terrestrial ecosystems via land applied biosolids enriched with nanoparticles that have been transformed during the wastewater treatment process (Gottschalk et al. 2009; Barton et al. 2015; Garner et al. 2017). In the case of silver, it is accepted that Ag ENMs will be fully or partially sulfidized during wastewater treatment, and that these sulfidized particles are much less toxic than pristine Ag ENMs (Kaegi et al. 2013; Levard et al. 2013). Indeed, Suresh et al. (2011) found that concentrations even up to 1.4mM of 9 nm sulfidized Ag ENM (sAg ENM) were not toxic to E. coli, Sh. oneidensis, or B. subtilis; although, the tested particles had a capping protein/peptide which may have influenced particle–cell interactions. Additionally, another study found a strong negative correlation between the degree of Ag ENM sulfidation and toxicity to E. coli (Reinsch et al. 2012). Others have found that exposure of B. subtilis
3610 to PVP-Ag ENMs results in fully sulfidized Ag ENMs and that exposure of the ENMs to the B. subtilis secretome results in partially sulfidized Ag ENMs; both fully and partially sulfidized ENMs were not toxic (Eymard-Vernain, Luche, et al. 2018). Lewis et al. (2017) reported limited toxicity of 300 mM sAg ENMs to B. amyloliquefaciens GB03, P. putida UW4, and Si. meliloti 2011 that was not explained by the abiotically dissolved fraction of the ENMs, indicating that particle–cell interactions play a key role in sAg ENM toxicity.
From these findings, it is apparent that sAg ENMs induce minimal toxic responses in PGPR; however, experimental systems in which they do exhibit toxicity could be useful in examining particle-cell interactions in the absence of confounding free ions in solution. Additionally, while the longterm environmental impact of sAg ENMs remains generally unclear, some work (discussed in greater detail elsewhere in this review) suggests these transformants can have unexpected ecological and plant physiological ramifications (Colman et al. 2013; Wang et al. 2015), so examining toxicological responses to sAg ENMs remains an important field of investigation.

sections.heading: ZnO ENMs and PGPR in perspective
sections.text:
Zinc-containing ENMs represent a large portion of nanomaterials expected to be enriched in biosolidsamended soils at an exponential rate (Gottschalk et al. 2009; Barton et al. 2015; Garner et al. 2017). Several nanotoxicological studies have examined the effects of ZnO ENMs on PGPR and related species (Table S2). In the soil bacterium, Cupriavidus necator JMP134, 1–3 nm acetate-stabilized ZnO ENMs elicited differential global protein expression profiles compared with Zn2þ supplied as zinc acetate (Zn-OAc) (Neal et al. 2012). While it remains unclear what nanoscale properties may play a role in the observed responses, ZnO ENMs elicited expression of membrane proteins not expressed with Zn2þ exposure. Unfortunately, the proteomic responses of bacteria to ZnO ENMs and nanoparticles generally remain unexplored, so there is little with which to compare these results. Nevertheless, this study demonstrated the power of examining proteomic responses to tease out differences between ENM and ion-driven toxic responses.
The effects of ZnO ENMs and Zn2þ have also been investigated by others and there has been some investigation into the influence of surface charge on ZnO ENM toxicity. Jiang, Mashayekhi, et al. (2009) found that bulk ZnO and ZnO ENMs were more toxic than Zn2þ in terms of survival percentage of E. coli and P. fluorescens. This is particularly important because the Zn2þ ion controls were representative of the dissolved fraction of ZnOmicro/nanoparticles. Complete mortality was observed in all organisms at 306 mM ZnO ENMs (20 nm, zeta-potential¼ 5mV). Exposures were performed in 16.8mM NaCl to avoid changes to particle characteristics; however, nearly all particles were either present as dispersed particles or aggregates with >200 nm hydrodynamic diameter, with the exception of SiO2 ENMs (46 nm) (Jiang, Mashayekhi, et al. 2009). Aggregates of all particles found on the bacterial surfaces via TEM were generally smaller than those found in the medium without bacteria. Zeta-potential measurements in 1 g L 1 NaCl at pH 6.5 suggested strong electrostatic attraction between the negatively charged bacterial surfaces and the positively charged Al2O3 and SiO2 particles (though the positive charge of SiO2 ENMs is atypical; Dove and Craven 2005; Thomassen et al. 2010; Andr e et al. 2017). To explain the strong association of the negatively charged ZnO ENMs to the bacterial surfaces, the researchers speculated it was due to the ‘carboxyl-, amide-, phosphate-, hydroxyl-, and carbohydrate-related moieties in the bacterial cell wall’; however, no investigation into the biochemical or molecular mechanisms governing the particle–cell interactions was performed. Mallevre et al. (2014) exposed P. putida BS566::luxCDABE to 42nm ZnO ENMs and found, compared with LB medium, artificial wastewater (AW) increased z-average diameter from 200 to 1600nm and decreased dissolution from 40 to 2.5%, purportedly led to complete mitigation of ZnO ENM toxicity in AW. Additionally, the AW used by Mallevre et al. (2014) contained 0.1mM CaCl2 which has been shown to alter electrostatically driven interactions of ZnO ENMs and P. aeruginosa PAO1 cells (Feris et al. 2010). In another study, Dimkpa, Calder, Britt, et al. (2011) found 7.7mM ZnO ENMs (<100nm), bulk Zn, or ionic zinc, reduced Log10 CFU mL
1 of P. chlororaphis O6 by about 12.5, 6, and 10%, respectively. ZnO ENMs reduced the surface charge of live bacteria at pH 6 ( 22 to
16mV), but not at pH 7. It is clear both ZnO ENMs and ions generate toxic responses in PGPR and related species and that surface charge might have some effect; however, the conflicting results regarding ion versus ENM toxicity is likely from differences in experimental design and bacterial strains used. Furthermore, the presence of ions in solution is known to influence the surface charge of colloids (James and Healy 1972), so future researchers should consider this when designing experiments and measuring surface chemistries.
Investigations into the toxicity of ZnO ENMs to bacteria have resulted in conflicting results regarding what organisms are most susceptible. As discussed in the previous paragraph, Jiang, Mashayekhi, et al. (2009) reported B. subtilis, P. fluorescens, and E. coli were equally susceptible to 306 mM ZnO ENMs. Other studies have found various strains of B. subtilis were more sensitive to Zncontaining ENMs than other bacteria, including, P. putida and E. coli (Li et al. 2010), S. aureus ATCC 25923 (Rago et al. 2014), E. coli DH5a (Adams et al. 2006), and others (Sinha et al. 2011; Kim and An 2012). However, Jones et al. (2008) found that Staphylococcus epidermidis 1487 and Streptococcus pyogenes NZ131 were both more sensitive to 8 nm ZnO ENMs in LB medium compared with B. subtilis 168 and the least sensitive tested organism, S. aureus N315. In at least one study, 1.3mM of 10–70 nm ZnO ENMs was required to reduce the viability of B. subtilis (unreported strain) by 50% (Baek and An 2011). Others observed 306 mM ZnO ENMs was required to completely inhibit the growth of a Pseudomonas species (Soni et al. 2017), which is similar to the findings of Jiang, Mashayekhi, et al. (2009b). Raj et al. (2016) reported a ZOI of 18–20mm with ZnO ENM nanorods (with one dimension <100 nm) exposure in P. aeruginosa, which is similar to the results of others in related strains (Azam et al. 2012; Stan et al. 2016). Shah et al. (2016) reported ZnO ENM (29 nm) exposure results in a ZOI of 13 and 22mm for B. cereus and B. subtilis, respectively, which is similar to the 23mm ZOI reported by Khan et al. (2016) for B. subtilis exposed to 3–25 nm ZnO ENMs. Others have reported a ZOI of 14mm for B. subtilis exposed to 14–27 nm biogenic ZnO ENMs (derived from multiple species; Table S2; Stan et al. 2016), and one study showed that ZnS:Mn ENM (3.6 nm) exposure
yielded a ZOI of 12mm in B. subtilis (Ali et al. 2016). Future researchers might clarify these findings by incorporating many strains of PGPR along with various forms of ZnO ENM to determine the effect of particle characteristics and bacterial biology on toxic responses.
Few studies have examined the influence of ZnO ENMs on bacterial biofilm formation in PGPR or related bacteria. One relatively thorough investigation by Lee et al. (2014) found that Zn2þ supplied as either ZnCl2 or Zn(NO3)2 nearly completely inhibited biofilm formation at 5mM, while a similar response was observed at 1mM of 50 nm ZnO ENMs in P. aeruginosa PAO1. Additionally, sublethal ZnO ENM exposure (0.5mM) increased cellular hydrophobicity and pyoverdine production ( 50%) and reduced production of pyochelin (a siderophore) by 60%, Pseudomonas quinolone signal (PQS) by 40%, and pyocyanin (a toxin) by 70%. Microarray analyses revealed induction of several genes associated with zinc efflux (czc operon, up to 19-fold increase) and transcriptional regulators involved in different biological processes (opdT – a porin, ptrA – Pseudomonas type III repressor A, 14- and 63-fold increase, respectively), while repressed expression was observed in pyocyanin-related genes ( 3.3- to 4.5-fold change). Some evidence for particle-specific effects was found when either 0.1mM ZnO ENM or 1mM ZnCl2 resulted in 40% reduction in hemolytic activity, but additional research is required to understand the underlying mechanism of this response. For instance, ion controls should be used in future microarray experiments to distinguish gene expression patterns driven by particle exposure from those induced by ions.
Garc ıa-Lara et al. (2015) reported 1mM 65nm ZnO ENMs (zeta-potential¼ 11.1mV) reduced biofilm formation (26–100%), production of elastase (90%), and pyocyanin (50–90%) in many tested strains of P. aeruginosa, including six clinical strains, two PA14 gallium-resistant mutants, a C-30-resistant mutant, and four strains isolated from various nonterrestrial environments. No ion controls were used in this study, so future work should clarify the role of ZnO ENMs compared with Zn2þ in the reported response. Another study examining the toxicity in P. putida KT2440 demonstrated ZnO ENM exposure reduced biofilm adenosine triphosphate (up to
90%) and that removal of extracellular polymeric substances enhanced the phenomenon by additionally decreasing metabolic activity by >75% during ZnO ENM exposure (Ouyang et al. 2017). The authors of this study also reported that the addition of humic acid reduced the toxicity of ZnO ENMs to biofilms and that toxicity was primarily driven by the dissolved fraction.
An agriculturally relevant study showed ZnO treatment did not reduce Phaseolus (Ph.) vulgaris (bean) root colonization by P. chlororaphis O6 (Dimkpa et al. 2014). Additionally, the antifungal behavior of P. chlororaphis O6 was not inhibited by ZnO ENM exposure (Dimkpa et al. 2013), but this was determined via growth inhibition tests of the fungal pathogen, Fusarium graminearum, cultured on agar plates (i.e. authors did not test the effects of ZnO ENM exposure on biocontrol of the pathogen in planta). Still, this study draws attention to the broader issue of the need for more nanotoxicological investigations of plant-microbe interactions and provides a subject for future research. Others reported that ZnO ENM (<100 nm) toxicity in Ph. vulgaris and Solanum (So.) lycopersicon (tomato) was similar to ZnSO4 and bulk zinc, in terms of diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid-triethanolamine (DTPATEA) extractable zinc (Garc ıa-G omez et al. 2017).
Compared with Ag ENMs, ZnO ENMs are generally far less toxic, but there is still much left to understand regarding ZnO ENM–PGPR interactions. Specifically, some studies suggest nanoscale zinc induces greater toxicity than ions, or at least induces nano-specific responses. Such studies warrant deeper investigation to reveal the biological and physicochemical mechanisms of these responses. Further, more work should be aimed at examining the influence of ZnO ENMs on biofilm formation and signaling, along with transcriptomic, metabolomic, and proteomic responses. This is of particular importance given the ongoing study of ZnO ENMbased fertilizers (Wang, Liu, et al. 2016; Dimkpa et al. 2017; Garc ıa-G omez et al. 2017) and the role of biofilm formation in plant-bacteria interactions (Angus and Hirsch 2013).

sections.heading: TiO2 ENMs and PGPR in perspective
sections.text:
Titanium-containing nanoparticles are expected to represent the largest mass of metal-containing
nanoparticles released to the environment (Gottschalk et al. 2009; Sun et al. 2014; Sun et al. 2017), and research is growing regarding the effects of TiO2 ENMs on PGPR (Table S3). Some studies suggest that these particles elicit low toxicity even at high concentrations; however, TiO2 ENM toxicity is enhanced by photo-activation (vide infra) and many studies do not explore this aspect of TiO2 ENM toxicity. Jiang, Mashayekhi, et al. (2009) found the TiO2 nano and microparticles (418mM) were non-toxic to all bacterial species tested. Similarly, Adams et al. (2006) found 10.5mM TiO2 (330 nm) did not inhibit the growth of B. subtilis and only moderately inhibited the growth of E. coli (15% growth inhibition). TiO2 ENM exposure has also been found to inhibit autolysis in B. subtilis ATCC 6051 (McGivney et al. 2017). Other pure bacterial culture studies reported low toxicity of TiO2 ENMs (Combarros et al. 2016), especially compared with Ag or ZnO ENMs (Tables S1, S2, and S3), but some authors have noted significant toxic effects of TiO2 to bacteria at relatively low concentrations.
For instance, Kumari et al. (2014) reported <21 mM TiO2 ENM (25 nm) exposure reduced viability of B. altitudinis VITLWS1 (20–25%), B. subtilis VITLWS2 (22–25%), P. aeruginosa VITLWS3 (23–27%), and consortia of all three tested species (10–20%). Viability responses to exposures performed in light and dark were very similar, while Binh et al. (2014) observed light-enhanced toxicity of 23–82 nm TiO2 ENM in B. subtilis (ATCC 21183), with 522 mM TiO2 ENMs results in about 10% or 90% viability in light and dark, respectively. The differences in observed responses are likely due to the use of visible light by Kumari et al. (2014) versus simulated solar illumination (280–849 nm and 200 W (m2) 1 by Binh et al. (2014). The importance of wavelength choice for illumination of TiO2 ENMs studies has been documented elsewhere (Park et al. 2012) and the interaction of titanium with UV-light is well known. The studies by Binh et al. (2014) and Kumari et al. (2014) used particles which were in micron-sized aggregates in the exposure media, nonetheless, Binh et al. (2014) also found low exposures of TiO2 ENM (52 mM) in simulated solar illumination reduced viability by 40% in B. subtilis. Others reported coating glass surfaces with 5.6 nm TiO2 ENMs (photoactivated) resulted in greater than 99.9% reduction in viability of P. putida CECT in biofilms;
however, biofilms were not completely removed (Jalvo et al. 2017).
As discussed by Kubacka et al. (2014), the biocidal properties of TiO2 ENM containing materials emerge primarily from electron–hole carriers at the surface of photo-activated materials. Still, knowledge regarding bacterial responses to titaniumbased ENM remains limited. Kubacka et al. (2014) examined the responses of P. aeruginosa PAO1 to 9 nm UV-activated TiO2 nanocomposites (ethylenevinyl alcohol (EVOH) films) and observed several nano-specific cellular responses compared with UVþ EVOH controls. Microarray analysis revealed strong upregulation of genes related to detoxification (6.7- to 145-fold), carbohydrate metabolism (10- to 67-fold), transport (12-fold), and amino acid metabolism (10-fold), and strong downregulation of inorganic phosphate uptake genes ( 9-fold). Cellto-cell signaling was also likely inhibited by a reduction of spermidine biosynthesis via a 9.6-fold decrease in an S-adenosylmethionine decarboxylase and an 8.5-fold decrease in spermidine synthase. Differential responses of several genes involved in maintaining cell wall structure were also observed. The authors suggested that this finding, along with the existing body of evidence, demonstrated UVactivated TiO2 exposure leads to a weakened cell wall which was compensated for by strengthening the underlying membrane with additional proteins and lipids. Additionally, changes in metabolism were likely because coenzyme-independent respiratory chains were downregulated. Heme group degradation was inhibited 8.5-fold. In silico, analysis of P. aeruginosa PAO1 revealed TiO2 ENMs targets the katA gene, and that katA directly interacts with DnaK, Hfq, RpoS, and RpoA. DnaK and Hfq are important for protein synthesis and stress responses while RpoA and RpoS are important for RNA biosynthesis, with RpoS also being important for quorum sensing, rhamnolipid/swarming motility, and the Type VI bacterial secretion system (Anupama et al. 2018). These results highlight the complexity of the TiO2 ENM toxicity and call for research regarding the universality of such responses among bacteria and the degree of crosstalk among the toxic responses.
TiO2 ENMs are generally less toxic to PGPR and related species than Ag or ZnO ENMs; however, the large amounts of TiO2 ENMs expected to be
released to the environment makes them an environmental concern. Additionally, novel responses to ENMs are still being discovered. For instance, exposure of B. subtilis 3610 to TiO2 ENMs completely inhibited cellular competence while ZnO ENMs enhanced competence and Ag ENMs had no effect (Eymard-Vernain et al. 2018). The toxicity of TiO2 ENMs is heavily modulated by the wavelength of light used in photo-activation, which should be considered in nanotoxicological studies. There is evidence to suggest that TiO2 ENMs can elicit metabolic and transcriptomic responses in bacteria, but the phenomena have not been examined in actual plant growth-promoting species. Given that minimal toxicity is often observed in response to TiO2 ENMs in terms of viability/mortality, a multi-omics approach could reveal previously unobserved physiological responses.
ENMs and symbiotic nitrogen-fixing bacteria
Sinorhizobium meliloti is a soil bacterium capable of fixing N2 through a symbiotic relationship with plant species from the Medicago, Melilotus, and Trigonella genera (Roumiantseva et al. 2002). The symbiosis between Si. meliloti and the model legume, Medicago truncatula, is currently being exploited to dissect the biochemical and molecular mechanisms of the legume symbiosis and much more. The plant growth-promoting abilities of Si. meliloti in non-leguminous plants (lettuce) have been known for some time now (Galleguillos et al. 2000), but the mechanism remains obscured. Some strains of rhizobia have been shown to exhibit ACC deaminase activity which may lead to plant growth promoting activities, but it is not thought that Si. meliloti 1021 possesses the ACC deaminase gene (Ma et al. 2003).
There are few studies concerning nanotoxicity in Si. meliloti, or any other N-fixing legume microsymbiont for that matter. One relatively thorough investigation assesses the toxicity of microscale aggregates of ZnO (10nm primary size, 893–1302nm suspended size, zeta-potential¼ 26 to 20mV) and CeO2 ENMs (10nm primary size, 1758–2252nm suspended size, zeta-potential¼ 20 to 18mV) to Si. meliloti Rm 1021 (Bandyopadhyay et al. 2012). This is particularly important because it is known that aggregates exhibit different levels of toxicity compared with
nanoparticles. This could be why the authors found a weak relationship between CeO2 ENM concentration and toxic response in terms of growth. Furthermore, complexation of zinc and ceria ions was likely to occur in the yeast mannitol broth (YMB) medium used to expose the cells, which may also partially explain the weak correlation noted between ion concentration and growth response. Nevertheless, they found that 0.5, 1, and 2mM ZnO ENMs completely inhibited growth, while equimolar concentrations of Zn2þ did not. This is likely a result of the particles acting as a unique delivery mechanism of Zn2þ ions to the cell surface, whereas, any dissolved free Zn2þ ions in solution were likely rendered less bioavailable through complexation and possibly precipitation. Indeed, scanning-TEM micrographs along with energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) data showed a clear association of both ZnO ENMs and CeO2 ENMs with Si. meliloti cells. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis of EPS extracted from exposed cells showed CeO2 ENMs or ZnO ENMs to alter shape and intensities of absorption bands indicative of interactions of ENMs with proteins and polysaccharides. These changes in FTIR spectra appeared to be more dose-dependent with ZnO ENMs versus the less toxic CeO2 ENMs.
Another study investigated the role of EPS in modulating sodium citrate-stabilized Ag ENM (10–100 nm) toxicity by exposing Si. meliloti Rm 1021, Rm 7096 – an EPS overproducing mutant, and Rm 7210 – an EPS lacking mutant in LB medium (Joshi et al. 2012). Consistent with the most literature, EPS over-producing mutants exhibited greater tolerance of Ag ENMs. Particle size was estimated in the medium and dissolution measurements, along with responses to silver ion controls, suggested that abiotic Ag ENM dissolution did not explain the observed responses (which is different than the results of Lewis et al. (2017), where the abiotically dissolved fraction was reported to likely explain the toxicity of PVP-Ag ENMs to Si. meliloti 2011.) E. coli JM109/pEdinbrick1, which produces low levels of colanic acid, was also exposed to 56–76 mM Ag ENMs, and the addition of an EPS analog, xanthan, increased survival by 10–25%. Furthermore, the addition of EPS purified from E. coli JM109/pRscA2 increased survival by 40% in response to 60 mM Ag ENMs in E. coli/BW25113/
Dyhak, which produces low levels of polysaccharides.
A full review of the effects of ENM exposure on plant–microbe interactions is beyond the scope of this review; however, it is useful to provide highlights of what is currently known regarding N-fixing microsymbionts in the context of their host plants. There is relatively little known concerning the influence of ENM on root nodule development or function. From an environmental protection perspective, the most relevant study to date examined the physiological responses of Medicago truncatula A17 grown in Si. meliloti Rm 2011 inoculated soils amended with field composted biosolids containing Ag, ZnO, and TiO2 ENMs or AgNO3, ZnSO4, and micron-sized TiO2 (Judy, McNear, et al. 2015). In this study, the ENM-enriched biosolids significantly reduced the number of root nodules (<1 nodule/ plant) observed after 30 d of growth compared with the no metal control and the dissolved/bulk enriched biosolids amended treatment, which had 4–6 nodules/plant, respectively. This effect did not appear to be a result of enhanced plant health, as ENM treatment significantly decreased fresh shoot biomass (32%), dried root biomass (35%), and shoot length (19%). There was a reduction in Si. meliloti CFU estimates by bulk/dissolved and ENM treatments (90 and 86% reduction, respectively); however, reduced nodulation did not appear to be a result of decreased survival of Si. meliloti in the ENM treatments, as nodulation was not influenced by bulk/dissolved treatments. Regardless, it remains unclear if ENM-specific stress responses may have influenced Si. meliloti physiology, thereby reducing the symbiotic capacity of the organism. The authors suggest that enhanced zinc uptake observed in the ENM treatments likely explains much of the observed responses, but further research is required because plants were co-exposed to several metals at once. Furthermore, additional experiments should be duplicated using biosolids from multiple sources with varying compositions to determine the influence of biosolid specific factors.
Nevertheless, ENMs were found to elicit distinct toxicogenomic responses in plants compared with the other treatments as determined via microarray analyses (Chen et al. 2015). Importantly, the authors observed differential expression of several nodulation
related genes from various gene ontology categories, including, nodulation, nodule morphogenesis, and Nfixation. Also, downregulation of several nitrogen metabolism-related genes in roots and many other metabolic pathway GOs was observed in plants exposed to ENMs, including those related to nodulation such as flavonoid metabolic/biosynthetic processes and phenyl-propanoid metabolic/biosynthetic processes. These results suggest that ENM exposure can alter basic plant metabolism, which provides a basis for a future investigation into the physiological responses of legumes (and other plants) to ENM enriched materials.
Research with more agronomically relevant N-fixing legumes has also shown that specific ENMs may disrupt the process of nodulation and negatively affect plant health. For instance, 7mM ZnO (<50 nm) reduced nodule area by 66% 14 d postinoculation, and 2mM TiO2 (35 nm) reduced nodule area by 53% 7d post-inoculation in hydroponically grown Pisum sativum L (Fan et al. 2014; Huang et al. 2014). Additionally, the process of nodule development, including the onset of nitrogen fixation, was delayed by TiO2 or ZnO ENM exposure. In red clover (Trifolium pretense), TiO2 ENM exposure was shown to reduce N-fixation by the endosymbiont, Rhizobium trifolii, by 30–54% (Moll et al. 2016). In soybeans (Glycine max), ethylene reduction assays showed high concentrations of CeO2 ENMs (3.6–7.1mmol kg
1) significantly reduced nitrogen fixation >80% in root nodules (Priester et al. 2012) and ZnO ENMs hindered development and inhibited reproduction (Yoon et al. 2014). Additionally, ZnO and CeO2 nanoparticles in soybeans are thought to differentially elicit genotoxicity as determined through RAPD analysis for DNA damage and mutations (L opezMoreno et al. 2010). Another study examining responses of Medicago sativa L inoculated with an unspecified strain of Si. meliloti showed 11.5mM bulk or ionic zinc decreased seed germination (63 and 75%, respectively), while 11.5mM ZnO ENMs resulted in a non-statistically significant increase (Bandyopadhyay et al. 2015). Furthermore, 3.8, 7.7, and 11.5mM ZnO ENM reduced root and shoot biomass (83 and 33%, respectively), while equimolar concentrations of ZnCl2 reduced shoot biomass similarly, but only 11.5mM reduced shoot biomass (33%). Interestingly, 7.7 and 11.5mM
bulk Zn resulted in large increases ( 400%) in shoot biomass. These results, in aggregate, show that legumes and the process of nodulation and nitrogen fixation are sensitive to various ENMs likely as a confluence of several physiological phenomena.
ENMs, soil microbial communities, and plant–microbe interactions

sections.heading: Ag ENMs, soil microbial communities, and plant–microbe interactions
sections.text:
The influence of ENMs on soil microbial communities remains largely unexplored (Simonin and Richaume 2015), but interest is growing (McKee and Filser 2016). Amendment of terrestrial mesocosms with biosolids containing ENMs or metals to a concentration of 1.3mmol kg 1 PVP-Ag ENM or 5.2mmol kg 1 AgNO3 resulted in no change in total plant biomass compared with biosolids only controls (Colman et al. 2013). However, both metal treatments reduced aboveground biomass of Microstegium vimineum by 32% while increasing belowground biomass by 88%. Microbial community composition was altered to a greater degree by Ag ENMs than Agþ when compared with biosolid-only controls at 1 and 50d post-exposure. The Ag ENMs reduced microbial biomass (35%), leucine aminopeptidase activity (an extracellular proteolytic enzyme) (52%), and phosphatase activity (27%), while N2O production was increased 4.5-fold. In another study, amendment of soils with 9.3mmol Ag ENMs g soil 1 resulted in decreased activities of urease (90%), fluorescein diacetate hydrolase (50%), arylsulfatase (50%), b-glucosidase (20%), dehydrogenase (70%), and acid-phosphatase (20%) (Shin et al. 2012). Silver ions at concentrations representative of the dissolved fraction of the Ag ENM treatments had no influence on soil enzyme activities; however, particle dissolution was estimated by sequentially filtering soil suspensions through filter papers followed by nylon filters and it is unclear if the authors controlled for ion sorption to the membranes. Regardless, the enhanced chronic low-dose response of the microbial community to Ag ENMs when compared with ions shows the complexity of eco-nanotoxicological studies and the care needed when extrapolating laboratory results to environmental
studies. Others have found addition of 100 mg L 1 PVP–Ag ENMs (58 nm) reduced N and P cycling efficiency in a constructed wetland. After 94days, 95.72% of Ag was retained in the constructed wetland soil and shifts in microbial community structure were observed with Ag ENM exposure (Cao et al. 2018). Conversely, others reported the addition of 9.3mM PVP-coated (74.2 nm, zeta-potential¼ 9.37) or aged (67.9 nm, zeta-potential¼ 4.17) Ag ENMs maintained long-term microbial diversity in activated biosolids bioreactors (Sheng et al. 2018).
In another study, relatively low doses of Ag ENMs (0.03, 0.3, and 3mmol/g dry soil) had no influence on soil enzyme activities, but a reduction in microbial biomass (up to 34%) and net N mineralization (up to 16%) coupled to an increased metabolic quotient (89%) were reported (H€ansch and Emmerling 2010). Similarly, arctic soils amended with 2mmol kg 1 Ag, 3.5mmol/kg CuO, and 7.8mmol kg 1 SiO2 ENMs had decreased microbial biomass after 6months (Kumar et al. 2012) and Ag ENM amendment alone was found to alter microbial community structure (Kumar et al. 2011). Calder et al. (2012) used sand and soil slurry microcosms to study the influence of soil components on Ag ENM and ion toxicity to P. chlororaphis O6. Sand and soil were autoclaved twice before inoculating with bacteria with and without Ag ENMs or ions. After 4d of incubation, CFU counts were determined by serial diluting the slurry in water and plating. Despite the fact that many soil components were likely altered during autoclaving, up to 28mM Ag ENMs or ions were both found to be essentially non-toxic in the soil–microbe mixtures. In sand, roughly a 40% reduction in CFUs was observed in response to 9.3mM Ag ENM. Addition of pore-water (isolated from metal free soil slurries; 0.083mL isolated pore-water g sand 1) completely mitigated toxicity while humic acid ( 8.3mg humic acid g sand 1) restored CFU counts to 90%. Soil pore-water and humic acid amendments restored CFU counts to >75% when applied with 28mM Ag ENM, which otherwise resulted in total loss of culturable cells. Interestingly, soil pore-water completely mitigated the toxicity of 2.8mM and 9.3mM Agþ, but humic acid was shown to enhance the toxicity of 2.8 and 9.3mM Agþ, leading to 100% mortality at 9.3mM Agþ. The difference in cell recovery observed in the presence of pore-water or humic acid when Ag ENMs were supplied was largely a function of measured
free ion concentrations, where the presence of both of these substances reduced free Agþ concentrations, with the effect of the pore-water being greater. These studies suggest soil microbiomes are influenced by ENM exposure; however, the underlying mechanisms governing shifts in microbial communities and plant–microbe interactions remain poorly understood. Of importance is the lack of understanding in how such responses might influence agricultural productivity.
One agriculturally relevant study with tomatoes revealed a reduction in arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) colonization in response to 930mmol kg 1 PVP-Ag ENMs or AgNO3 (95 and 84% reduction, respectively), or 93mmol kg 1 sAg ENM amended biosolids (38% reduction) (Judy, Kirby, et al. 2015). All tested concentrations of Agþ (9.3, 93, and 930mmol kg 1) and 93 or 930mmol kg 1 PVP-Ag ENMs reduced total soil microbial biomass (up to 28%) and abundance of Gram-negative bacteria (up to 31%). Interestingly, 9.3 or 930mmol kg 1 Ag2S treatments reduced total microbial biomass (18%) and Gram-negative bacteria abundance (17%), but not 93mmol kg 1. Gram-positive bacteria abundance was reduced by 930mmol kg 1 Agþ (28%), PVP-Ag ENMs (25%), and sAg ENMs (12%) and 93mmol kg 1 Agþ (21%), while bacterial abundance was reduced across all treatments. In addition to the noted effects on AMF colonization, total soil fungal abundance was reduced by 17% in response to 9.3mmol kg 1 Ag2SENMs, 930mmol kg
1 PVP-Ag ENMs, and 9.3 and 930mmol kg 1 Agþ. The 93mmol kg 1 Agþ treatment resulted in a doubling of the dry shoot biomass due to what the authors suggest could be potential hormetic responses; however, alternative hypotheses might include possible suppression of plant pathogens in the biosolids amended soils due to the presence of Agþ.
Mesocosm studies have shown that relatively low environmental concentrations of Ag ENMs, thought to likely be sulfidized, altered microbial community structure, reduced plant shoot biomass, increased nitrous oxide production, and influenced several other ecologically relevant processes; even to a greater extent than AgNO3 applied at 4-fold higher concentrations (Colman et al. 2013). Also, it was shown that sAg ENMs may reduce root and shoot biomass in Vigna unguiculata L. Walp. (shoot and root biomass decreased: 31–52%) and Triticum
aestivum L. (shoot and root biomass decreased: 15–35%), but this was only evident after prolonged exposure (2weeks) (Wang et al. 2015). While it is clear that sAg ENMs are generally less toxic than pristine Ag ENMs, the long-term impact of these particles on terrestrial ecosystems has yet to be investigated. Because large quantities of ENMs are entering the waste-stream and sulfidation is a major transformation pathway, it is important to understand the potential effects of these particles on fundamental ecological processes.
Other ENMs, soil microbial communities, and plant–microbe interactions
Ge et al. (2011) found soils amended with 10.5, 21, or 42mmol kg 1 of TiO2 ENMs or 8, 15, or 31mmol kg 1 ZnO ENMs had decreased substrate-induced respiration (SIR) (up to 13%) and extractable DNA (up to 70%). At 15 and 60 d of exposure, extractable DNA reductions were concentration dependent, but were linear for TiO2 ENMs, and exponential for ZnO ENMs. Both particle types were found to result in shifts in microbial community structure, but the impact of ZnO ENMs was much more pronounced. Pyrosequencing revealed that ZnO and TiO2 led to a reduction in Rhizobiales, Bradyrhizobiaceae, Bradyrhizobium, and Methylbacteriaceae while increases were observed for Sphingomonadaceae, Streptomycetaceae, and Streptomyces (Ge et al. 2012). Interestingly, others have noted that copper and zinc nanoparticles decreased the abundance of Sphingomonadales and Flavobacteriales abundance (Collins et al. 2012). Nogueira et al. (2012) also found shifts in soil microbial community structure in response to TiO2 ENMs or Au nanorods. A study examining the effects of soil properties on TiO2 ENM toxicity found only one of six tested soils had decreased SIR (a soil with silty clay texture and high organic matter) (Simonin et al. 2015). Shifts in microbial community structure resulting from TiO2 ENMs exposure were also found to be more pronounced as soil moisture decreased, and may occur even though there are no changes in organic matter content, total N or C, C/N ratios, or bioavailable C (Ge et al. 2013). Soil amendment with biosolids containing mixtures of ENMs (Ag, Zn, and Ti) led to unique shifts in microbial community structure compared with bulk/dissolved metal controls; where
ENM treatment yielded significant reductions in most microbial groups as assessed via phospholipid fatty acid analysis (PLFA) analysis compared with metal free controls (Judy, McNear, et al. 2015). These results, along with those discussed in the previous section, show that a variety of ENMs can influence soil microbial communities which can be influenced by soil and ENM type.
Studies examining the effects of multiple ENMs on plant–microbe interactions have shown ENMs of different compositions can have differing effects. Du et al. (2011) found that 2mmol kg 1 TiO2 or 0.7mmol kg 1 ZnO ENMs decreased wheat shoot biomass (up to 13.4%) and potential soil peroxidase (up to 66%) and catalase activity (up to 40%), while ZnO ENMs reduced protease activity (35%) and TiO2 ENMs slightly increased urease activity (16%). Additionally, wheat root washings reduced the toxicity of CuO and ZnO ENMs to P. putida KT2440 (Martineau et al. 2014), while root colonization by P. chlororaphis or co-exposure with ZnO ENMs has been shown to reduce CuO ENM toxicity to Phaseolus vulgaris (Dimkpa et al. 2015). Others observed dissolution of CuO ENMs in wheat rhizosphere soils likely explained phytotoxicity. For instance, compared with ‘fresh’ CuO ENMs (freshly added), aged CuO ENMs (added 28 days prior to sowing plants) had a 36.5% increase in dissolution (diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (DTPA)-extractable Cu) and exposure to 7.9mmol kg 1 led to a 132% increase in root compactness (Gao et al. 2018). The effects of ZnO and CuO ENMs on P. chlororaphis O6 and wheat have been relatively thoroughly studied and has yielded a review on the subject, which suggests these ENMs can alter bacterial physiology (changes in phenazine, siderophore, and indole-3-acetic acid production) and plant physiology (changes in root hair (CuO ENMs) and lateral root proliferation (ZnO ENMs), shoot gene expression) (Anderson et al. 2017).
At least one study has examined the effects of TiO2 ENMs on PGPR activity in soils. In the presence or absence of TiO2 ENMs, Timmusk et al. (2018) inoculated wheat seedling roots with B. thuringiensis AZP2, Paenibacillus (Pa.) polymyxa A26, Alcaligenes (Al.) faecalis AF, and a Sfp type f-phosphopantetheinyl transferase deletion mutant, Pa. polymyxa A26Dsfp, or combinations of B. thuringiensis AZP2 and Pa. polymyxa A26 or Al. faecalis. These authors
also assessed the effect of the PGPR and TiO2 ENM treatments on drought, salt, and pathogen responses. Based on shoot biomass from peat soilgrown wheat, the findings suggest that TiO2 ENMs might enhance PGPR activity when plants are coinoculated with B. thuringiensis AZP2 and Pa. polymyxa A26 or Al. faecalis. No effect was observed by the TiO2 ENM treatment when plants were grown in sand. Additionally, the positive effect of PGPR and TiO2 ENMs on plants was greater when plants were stressed by drought, salt, or the fungal pathogen, Fusarium culmorum. Environmental scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging showed that TiO2 ENM treatment likely improved bacterial colonization of the root system, thereby enhancing plant growth promotion. The universality of these findings with regard to plant species, PGPR species, and ENM type is unclear; however, this study shows that PGPR–ENM interactions are complex in the soil environment and non-nutritive ENMs could be used to enhance PGPR activity.
Research regarding the influence of ENMs on soil microbial communities has shown they are often influenced in terms of composition and function by many different ENMs. Mechanisms governing these responses remain unknown and understanding is further obscured by the need for more clarity regarding relationships between microbial community structure and function in general; here, a multiomics approach to examining ENM–soil microbial community interactions would provide much needed insights. Plant–microbe interactions are also sensitive to ENMs. For instance, work with wheat and P. chlororaphis O6 has shown that ENM exposure can alter basic plant and microbe physiology and plant-microbe interactions in ways that could negatively impact crop production and plant growth promotion by the bacterium. More research is needed to obtain a strong working understanding of the mechanisms driving these (and other) responses and how the effects of ENMs differ from bulk and ionic forms. Additionally, examining plant–ENM interactions is an active field of study, a complete treatment of which is not possible in this review. Readers interested in plant–ENM interactions are directed to the work of others (Anderson et al. 2017; Garc ıa-G omez et al. 2017; Tripathi et al. 2017; Cota-Ruiz et al. 2018; Dimkpa 2018; Gao et al. 2018; L opez-Moreno et al. 2018; Reddy Pullagurala
et al. 2018; Ruotolo et al. 2018; Sturikova et al. 2018; V azquez N u~nez and de la Rosa- Alvarez 2018; Verma et al. 2018).

sections.heading: Conclusion and path forward
sections.text:
Considerable effort has been focused on understanding nanotoxicity in bacteria, but soil bacteria (and other micro-organisms) have remained largely neglected, particularly in the context of plant growth promotion and nutrient cycling. The complexities inherent to nanotoxicological studies (Figures 1–3) and the lack of in-depth particle characterization, along with the absence of broadly accepted standardized nanotoxicity/characterization assays, have also created uncertainty regarding the relevance of much of the existing literature to explaining mechanisms driving nano-specific responses in bacterial isolates, or microbial responses in soil–microbe–plant systems. Exposure solution pH, ionic strength, and general composition may all influence ENM properties (Figures 1–3) (Auffan et al. 2009; French et al. 2009; Jiang, Oberd€orster, et al. 2009; Jin et al. 2010; Tejamaya et al. 2012; Chambers et al. 2014; Reidy et al. 2013; Moore et al. 2015; Mudunkotuwa and Grassian 2015) and bacterial physiology. Furthermore, ENM properties in solution and in particle–cell interactions may be influenced by dissolution/aggregation status, ROS production, core/coating composition, surface chemistry, size, shape, and surface area (Figures 2 and 3; Ge et al. 2016; Schmid and Stoeger 2016). Bacteria may also respond to ENM exposures in several ways, some of which may influence particle physicochemical properties (i.e. release of ROS and other exudates/metabolites/lysates, other general changes to solution chemistry), and bacteria may generate nanoparticles from ions and/ or promote aggregation and dissolution of nanomaterials (Figures 1–3). Interactions with cells and culture medium or the environment may also result in biomolecular coronas surrounding the ENMs which may alter ENM activity (Docter et al. 2015; Ke et al. 2017; Ma et al. 2018; Markiewicz et al. 2018). Additionally, bacteria and other microbes may form multispecies aggregates, which has been proposed as a mechanism for reducing ENM toxicity (Figure 6; Tang et al. 2018). Ideally, all these possibilities should be considered and tested for when
designing nanotoxicity experiments, highlighting the cross-disciplinary and collaborative nature of nanotoxicology as an emerging discipline.
All future researchers working with pure-culture systems should perform full particle characterization in experimentally relevant exposure media. The literature suggests the primary particle characteristics of concern are concentration, dissolution measurements, aggregation status, size measurements, surface area, and surface charge (Wong et al. 2010; El Badawy et al. 2011; Raghupathi et al. 2011; Albanese et al. 2012; Georgantzopoulou et al. 2012; Ivask, Kurvet, et al. 2014; Schmid and Stoeger 2016; Lewis et al. 2017; Graf et al. 2018). Without these basic (yet, crucial) data, a mechanistic understanding of observed toxicological responses remains obscured. Further, appropriate positive and negative controls should be incorporated in nanotoxicological studies whenever possible. For instance, when ENM dissolution is observed, researchers can utilize ion controls, or, ideally, supernatants of ultracentrifuged ENM–medium mixtures (which also accounts for dissolution of capping agents). A multifaceted approach to experimental design must also be taken, where the effects of the toxicant on the organism are observed alongside the effects of the organism and exposure medium on the toxicant. It is now well known that abiotic and biotic reactions dictate particle behavior and particle–cell interactions during exposure. Again, neglecting these critical aspects of nanoparticle exposures inherently limits the ability
to interpret the observed response and determine the underlying mechanisms.
With the exception of a few studies, the current literature suggests ENM toxicity is generally less than that of ion equivalents (especially in the case of silver), but that ENMs can elicit nano-specific responses which are not solely based on the dissolved fraction. This latter point is particularly relevant when ENMs are not known to readily dissolve such as with TiO2 ENMs, sAg ENMs, and CeO2 ENMs. While reduction of metal ions to nanoparticles has been observed in metal resistant organisms (Kowshik et al. 2003; Parikh et al. 2008; Saratale et al. 2018), ENMs sometimes appear to be more toxic than their ionic counterparts, and while the phenomenon is not well understood, it is possible that dissolution at the particle–cell interface at least partially explains such responses. Not surprisingly, of the most abundantly produced ENMs, Ag ENMs generally present the greatest toxicity. Pureculture, single organism work has shown that bacterial strains within the same species can exhibit very different responses to ENMs while disparate bacterial strains can sometimes have very similar responses to ENMs. Additionally, the effect of ENM size and coating is not always clear with respect to toxicity, which appears to be heavily influenced by experimental parameters (Tables S1–S3). Work examining microbial communities has revealed that both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria are sensitive to ENMs along with fungal communities, but no clear mechanisms have been identified.
Figure 6. Drawing of a multispecies microbial aggregate. Such aggregates have been proposed to as a mechanism which reduces ENM toxicity in aquatic environments. EPS: extracellular polymeric substances. Figure used with permission from Tang et al. (2018).
Single organism and simplified plant–microbe interaction studies remain a valuable approach to understanding nano-specific effects in ENM–bacteria interactions, and have provided a strong basis for future research. Lacking in pure-culture, and in more complex media, is an understanding of the transcriptomic, metabolomic, and proteomic responses of PGPR to ENMs. It is clear that nanomaterials can elicit specific transcriptomic and proteomic responses in bacteria, but currently it is unknown how these responses may influence PGPR specifically, or alter their plant growth promoting activity and roles in other ecosystem services. Notwithstanding, studies on plant–microbe interactions have shown that both positive and negative responses may be observed depending on the type and concentration of the ENMs used in the study.
Several other significant knowledge gaps remain regarding ENM toxicity in PGPR. Except for EPS, it is not clear what, if any, role many extracellular products might play in nanotoxicological studies, including outer membrane vesicles or extracellular proteins (Figure 2). However, it has been suggested that bacteria might develop resistance mechanisms that are specific to nanoscale metals (compared with ions), including the production of flagellin, an adhesive flagellum protein (Pan a cek et al. 2018). Still, understanding of membrane–ENM interactions is limited and the influence of ENMs on lipid domain structure and function has not been explored in PGPR, nor have lipidomic responses in general. Additionally, little discussion has been focused on examining the interaction of ENMs and surface motifs in PGPR (e.g. pili, flagellum, etc.). Furthermore, the effects of ENMs on bacterial behavior and basic molecular, physiological, and metabolic functions have not been thoroughly investigated, particularly regarding bacterial behavior and molecular responses. For instance, while silver stress has been shown to induce several sRNAs (non-coding small RNAs) in B. cereus (Ganesh Babu et al. 2011), no studies have examined their role in ENM toxicity responses. The influence of ENMs on the CRISPR-Cas9 (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats-CRISPR-associated protein 9) system has also not been investigated, but could be worth examining given the implication that the CRISPR-Cas9 system might be involved in
DNA damage repair (Hakim et al. 2016; Haapaniemi et al. 2018).
Microbes in the rhizosphere and in the environment at large, are rarely (if ever), found alone. Some work has examined the response of PGPR biofilms to ENMs, but much remains unknown, particularly with respect to root colonization. Future research should examine multi-species interactions of ENMs with microbes that are both motile and present as biofilms on abiotic (e.g. mineral) and biotic (e.g. plant root) surfaces. As researchers attempt to clarify the results of the past decade of pure-culture-based nanotoxicological research, it is essential that future efforts are focused on more environmentally relevant conditions (i.e. soils). Examination of the effects of ENMs on plantmicrobe interactions in meso/microcosms, and ultimately, actual field sites, will provide a rich research topic for future researchers. Findings regarding ENM-induced changes in soil enzyme activities, nutrient cycling, and community interactions (reviewed by McKee and Filser 2016) should be examined with microbiome surveys, metagenomics, metametabolomics, metatranscriptomics, and metaproteomics to elucidate the biological mechanisms governing these crucial responses.
Additionally, ENM transformations in the soil and rhizosphere environment are still poorly understood; however, it is known that environmental transformations in soil can impact ENM toxicity and are driven by pH, organic matter, ionic strength, plant exudates, and microbial activity (Dimkpa 2018). As of now, nanoparticle characterization in more complex media (i.e. soil, biosolids, or sediments) remains a challenge, but advances are helping make that possible (Whitley et al. 2013; El Hadri et al. 2018; Gonz alez-Fuenzalida et al. 2018). This will be particularly important as the amount of nanomaterials entering terrestrial environments is increasing not only from current consumer and industrial uses, but also from emerging agricultural technologies (i.e. nanoparticle-based fertilizers, pesticides, and herbicides) (Wagner et al. 2016; Duhan et al. 2017). Because of the projected increase of nanotechnology-based agricultural products and ENM-enriched biosolids, PGPR and other beneficial micro-organisms will encounter new ENMs at an ever-increasing rate. Exposure of soil bacteria (and other biota) to mixtures of existing and novel ENMs
will also occur along with co-exposure to existing and emerging technologies and their associated byproducts. For instance, development of hybrid materials composed of mixtures of bacteria (or biologically-derived substances) and micro/nanomaterials is ongoing and such materials might provide novel solutions to problems spanning many issues important in environmental, medical, and industrial sciences (Liu et al. 2015; Sakimoto et al. 2016; Campuzano et al. 2017; Nangle et al. 2017); however, the environmental risk of these novel materials remains virtually unexplored and should be considered concurrently with their development.

metadata.abstractText: Deposition of engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) in various environmental compartments is projected to continue rising exponentially. Terrestrial environments are expected to be the largest repository for environmentally released ENMs. Because ENMs are enriched in biosolids during wastewater treatment, agriculturally applied biosolids facilitate ENM exposure of key soil microorganisms, such as plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria (PGPR). The ecological ramifications of increasing levels of ENM exposure of terrestrial micro-organisms are not clearly understood, but a growing body of research has investigated the toxicity of ENMs to various soil bacteria using a myriad of toxicity end-points and experimental procedures. This review explores what is known regarding ENM toxicity to important soil bacteria, with a focus on ENMs which are expected to accumulate in terrestrial ecosystems at the highest concentrations and pose the greatest potential threat to soil micro-organisms having potential indirect detrimental effects on plant growth. Knowledge gaps in the fundamental understanding of nanotoxicity to bacteria are identified, including the role of physicochemical properties of ENMs in toxicity responses, particularly in agriculturally relevant micro-organisms. Strategies for improving the impact of future research through the implementation of in-depth ENM characterization and use of necessary experimental controls are proposed. The future of nanotoxicological research employing microbial ecoreceptors is also explored, highlighting the need for continued research utilizing bacterial isolates while concurrently expanding efforts to study ENM–bacteria interactions in more complex environmentally relevant media, e.g. soil. Additionally, the particular importance of future work to extensively examine nanotoxicity in the context of bacterial ecosystem function, especially of plant growth-promoting agents, is proposed.
